title: USCGC Point Partridge (WPB-82305)
text:
USCGC "Point Partridge" (WPB-82305) was an constructed at the <a href="United%20States%20Coast%20Guard%20Yard">Coast Guard Yard</a> at <a href="Curtis%20Bay%2C%20Maryland">Curtis Bay, Maryland</a> in 1960 for use as a law enforcement and search and rescue patrol boat. Since the Coast Guard policy in 1960 was not to name <a href="United%20States%20Coast%20Guard%20Cutter">cutters</a> under in length, it was designated as "WPB-82305" when commissioned and acquired the name "Point Partridge" in January 1964 when the Coast Guard started naming all cutters longer than .
Construction and design details.
"Point Partridge" was built to accommodate an 8-man crew. She was powered by two VT600 <a href="Cummins">Cummins</a> diesel main drive engines and had two five-bladed propellers. The main drive engines were later replaced by VT800 Cummins engines. Water tank capacity was and fuel tank capacity was at 95% full. Engine exhaust was ported through the transom rather than through a conventional stack and this permitted a 360-degree view from the bridge; a feature that was very useful in search and rescue work as well as a combat environment.
The design specifications for "Point Partridge" included a steel hull for durability and an aluminum superstructure and longitudinally framed construction was used to save weight. Ease of operation with a small crew size was possible because of the non-manned main drive engine spaces. Controls and alarms located on the <a href="Bridge%20%28nautical%29">bridge</a> allowed one man operation of the cutter thus eliminating a live engineer <a href="Watch%20system">watch</a> in the engine room. Because of design, four men could operate the cutter; however, the need for resting watchstanders brought the crew size to eight men for normal domestic service. The <a href="Propeller">screw</a>s were designed for ease of replacement and could be changed without removing the cutter from the water. A clutch-in idle speed of three knots helped to conserve fuel on lengthy patrols and an eighteen knot maximum speed could get the cutter on scene quickly. Air-conditioned interior spaces were a part of the original design for the Point class cutter. Interior access to the deckhouse was through a <a href="ship%20floodability">watertight door</a> on the <a href="starboard%20side">starboard side</a> aft of the <a href="deckhouse">deckhouse</a>. The deckhouse contained the cabin for the officer-in-charge and the executive petty officer. The deckhouse also included a small arms locker, <a href="scuttlebutt">scuttlebutt</a>, a small desk and <a href="Head%20%28watercraft%29">head</a>. Access to the lower deck and engine room was down a ladder. At the bottom of the ladder was the <a href="Galley%20%28kitchen%29">galley</a>, <a href="mess">mess</a> and recreation deck. A watertight door at the front of the mess <a href="Bulkhead%20%28partition%29">bulkhead</a> led to the main crew quarters which was ten feet long and included six bunks that could be stowed, three bunks on each side. Forward of the bunks was the crew's head complete with a compact sink, shower and commode. Accommodations for a 13-man crew were installed for Vietnam service.
History.
After delivery in 1960, "Point Partridge" was assigned a homeport of <a href="Jonesport%2C%20Maine">Jonesport, Maine</a>, where she served as a law enforcement and search and rescue patrol boat.
At the request of the <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a>, in October 1965, she was alerted for service in <a href="South%20Vietnam">South Vietnam</a> and assigned to <a href="Coast%20Guard%20Squadron%20One">Coast Guard Squadron One</a> in support of <a href="Operation%20Market%20Time">Operation Market Time</a> along with 8 other Point class cutters. While the crew completed overseas training and weapons qualifications at <a href="Coast%20Guard%20Island">Coast Guard Island</a> and <a href="Parks%20Reserve%20Forces%20Training%20Area">Camp Parks, California</a>, "Point Partridge" was loaded onto a merchant ship, and transported to <a href="Subic%20Bay">Subic Bay</a>, <a href="Philippines">Philippines</a> arriving in January 1966 where she was refitted for combat service. Shipyard modifications included installation of new single-sideband radio equipment, additional floodlights, small arms lockers, bunks, additional sound-powered phone circuits, and the addition of 4 <a href="M2%20Browning%20machine%20gun">M2 machine guns</a>. The original <a href="Oerlikon%2020%20mm%20cannon">Oerlikon 20 mm cannon</a> was replaced with a combination over-under .50 caliber machine gun/81mm trigger-fired mortar that had been developed by the Coast Guard for service in Vietnam. For service in Vietnam, two officers were added to the crew complement to add seniority to the crew in the mission of interdicting vessels at sea.
"Point Partridge" was assigned to Division 13 of Squadron One to be based at <a href="Cat%20Lo%20Naval%20Base">Cat Lo Naval Base</a> near <a href="Vung%20Tau">Vung Tau</a>, along with , , , , , , and . After sea trials, the Division left Subic Bay for Cat Lo on 19 February 1966 in the company of , their temporary support ship. They arrived at their new duty station on 23 February and began patrolling the coastal waters near the <a href="Rung%20Sat%20Special%20Zone">Rung Sat Special Zone</a>. Duty consisted of boarding Vietnamese <a href="junk%20%28ship%29">junks</a> to search for contraband weapons and ammunition and check the identification papers of persons on board.
In February 1966 <a href="Operation%20Jackstay">Operation Jackstay</a> was conceived. The operation was a plan to deny food and water to the <a href="Viet%20Cong">Viet Cong</a> (VC) hidden in the Rung Sat Special Zone by cutting off resupply junks that had to cross the <a href="So%C3%A0i%20R%E1%BA%A1p%20River">Soài Rạp River</a>. The interdiction efforts depended on using boats that were heavily armed, highly maneuverable and had a shallow draft; all characteristics of the Point Class cutter. Some of the Squadron One cutters were assigned in March 1966 to the operation and began 24-hour patrols on 10 March. The operation ended on 6 April; however, "Point Partridge" remained on the river patrol and had several contacts with VC supply junks during April and May 1966. From 1 to 6 May she was involved every night with enemy junks or attacks from the shoreline. During the rest of the month she managed to capture two junks; one loaded with weapons and the other containing of rice.
In early 1970, "Point Partridge" and "Point Jefferson" acting as a team made over 300 boardings. Civic action programs conducted during the boardings by the two Squadron One cutters included handing out 3000 bars of soap as well as food items. Twelve Vietnamese were given medical treatment.
As a part of the <a href="Vietnamization">Vietnamization</a> program <a href="Republic%20of%20Vietnam%20Navy">Republic of Vietnam Navy</a> (RVNN) crewmen were assigned to the cutter for training purposes beginning in February 1969. After the crew of "Point Partridge" trained an RVNN replacement crew, she was turned over to the RVNN and recommissioned as RVNS "Bùi Viết Thành" (HQ-715), 27 March 1970.
